raw_text:
House prices suffer festive fall
 
 UK house prices fell 0.7% in December, according to figures from the Office of the Deputy Prime Minister.
 
 Nationally, house prices rose at an annual rate of 10.7% in December, less than the 13.7% rise the previous month. The average UK house price fell from £180,126 in November to £178,906, reflecting recent Land Registry figures confirming a slowdown in late 2004. All major UK regions, apart from Northern Ireland, experienced a fall in annual growth during December.
 
 December is traditionally a quiet month for the housing market because of Christmas celebrations. However, recent figures from the Land Registry - showing a big drop in sales between the last quarter of 2004 and the previous year - suggested the slowdown could be more than a seasonal blip. The volume of sales between October and December dropped by nearly a quarter from the same period in 2003, the Land Registry said. Although both the Office of the Deputy Prime Minister (ODPM) and the Land Registry figures point to a slowdown in the market, the most recent surveys from Nationwide and Halifax have indicated the market may be undergoing a revival. After registering falls at the back-end of 2004, Halifax said house prices rose by 0.8% in January and Nationwide reported a rise of 0.4% in the first month of the year.
llama3.2:1b: UK house prices fell 0.7% in December from £180,126 to £178,906.
House prices increased at an annual rate of 10.7% in December, but then decreased by 1.2 percentage points, or 1.4%, compared to the previous month, with a decline of £1,020 per property.
llama3.2:3b: UK house prices fell 0.7% in December, with annual growth slowing to 10.7%.
The average UK house price dropped from £180,126 to £178,906.
Regional sales declined by nearly a quarter from October-December 2003.
However, Nationwide and Halifax surveys indicate the market may be reviving, with January rises of 0.8% and 0.4%, respectively.
gemma2:2b: UK house prices fell 0.7% in December, with an annual rate of growth of 10.7%.
This slowdown is reflected in the Land Registry's figures showing decreased sales between October and December compared to the previous year.
However, some recent surveys suggest a revival of the market with small price increases reported by Halifax and Nationwide.
qwen2.5:0.5b: UK house prices fell in December by 0.7%, while the average price increased at an annual rate of 10.7%.
In November, UK house prices were at £180,126 per square meter.
Despite this, the Land Registry reported that sales declined between October and December.
Halifax suggested a revival for the market after falling at the end of 2004, while Nationwide indicated an increase in price for the first month of the year.
qwen2.5:1.5b: UK house prices fell 0.7% in December, with an annual rate of 10.7%, reversing from November's 13.7%.
Despite seasonal factors, slower growth suggests a broader market slowdown.
Nationally, all regions except Northern Ireland saw a fall in growth.
Sales volumes decreased by nearly a quarter compared to the previous year.
However, recent surveys indicate renewed interest, with Halifax and Nationwide reporting slight price increases for January.
qwen2.5:3b: UK house prices fell 0.7% in December, with an annual growth rate of 10.7%, down from 13.7% in November.
All major UK regions except Northern Ireland saw reduced annual growth in December.
The slowdown was attributed to recent Land Registry figures showing a decline in sales volume by nearly a quarter between October and December 2004, not just a seasonal effect.
While the ODPM and Land Registry data indicate market slowing, surveys suggest a potential market revival with increases reported by Halifax (0.8% rise in January) and Nationwide (0.4% rise).
opencoder:1.5b: The House prices have suffered festive fall according to UK data, with a drop followed by an increase in December, suggesting a slowdown during Christmas.
During December, house prices typically are less volatile and are driven more by festive seasons like Christmas.
This reflects recent figures from the Land Registry showing a significant decline in sales between October and December, indicating a slowdown experienced in 2004.
The market may be recovering after the fall, with sales increasing in January due to the rise in Halifax's figures.
It's also possible that Nationwide has experienced a further increase since the first month of 2005, reflecting the overall surge expected after the slowdown in 2004.
Overall, both the Office of the Deputy Prime Minister (ODPM) and the Land Registry figures show a recovery plan aimed at keeping up with any anticipated changes to the housing market.
Despite the apparent slowdown, both figures remain consistent with their reporting trends and likely suggesting continued growth.

tinyllama:1.1b:
UK House Prices Contracted Further During December, Decline From November Average Price of £178,906 to £178,906 Annually - Land Registry's Monthly Report Shows Decline in Sales

National Housing Market Continues to Struggle, UK House Prices Fall by 0.7% in December, According to Figures From Office of the Deputy Prime Minister and Nationwide Survey Reports House Prices Rise by 0.4%, Halifaxt Reports Decline

December was a quiet month for UK housing market due to Christmas celebrations, but recent figures from Land Registry showed a significant decrease in sales between October and December, indicating the market may be undergoing a revival.
Nationwide and Halifaxt reported house prices rose by 0.4% in January and 0.8% in January respectively.
Despite this, ODPM announced a decline in annual growth during December.
tinydolphin:1.1b: The fall in UK house prices in December was mainly due to a decline in sales during the holiday season, according to data from the Office of the Deputy Prime Minister (ODPM).
In contrast, the volume of sales between October and December dropped by nearly a quarter compared to the same period in 2003.
Both ODPM and Land Registry figures suggest that a slowdown in the market may be more than just a seasonal blip.
phi:2.7b: UK house prices fell 0.7% in December, with an annual rate of 10.7%.
The average price was £180,126 in November but only £178,906 in December due to slower growth during that time and a drop in sales between October and December according to the Land Registry.
However, surveys from Nationwide and Halifax show the market may be recovering with reports of rises in January and February respectively.

However, recent figures from the Land Registry showed a significant drop in sales between the last quarter of 2004 and the previous year, which suggests a more than seasonal slowdown.
The volume of sales between October and December dropped by nearly a quarter from the same period in 2003, according to the Land Registry.
Despite this, both the Office of the Deputy Prime Minister and the Land Registry figures point to a slowdown in the market, with recent surveys from Nationwide and Halifax indicating a revival.

stablelm2:1.6b: UK house prices fell 0.7% in December, according to Office of the Deputy Prime Minister figures.
This is the largest drop since last year's fourth quarter, with all major regions experiencing a fall in annual growth except Northern Ireland.
The slowdown could be more than seasonal, as the volume of sales between October and December dropped nearly 25%.
However, recent surveys from Nationwide and Halifax indicate a possible revival in the market after falls at the end of last year.
granite3.1-dense:2b: UK house prices decreased by 0.7% in December, marking a shift from the previous month's 13.7% annual growth rate, according to figures from the Office of the Deputy Prime Minister.
The average UK house price dropped from £180,126 in November to £178,906.
This decline was observed across all major UK regions except Northern Ireland.

December is typically a quiet period due to Christmas, but recent Land Registry data showed a significant decrease in sales between October and December, nearly a quarter lower than the same period in 2003.

Despite these indications of a slowdown, more recent surveys by Nationwide and Halifax suggest a potential market revival, with house prices rising by 0.8% for Halifax in January and 0.4% for Nationwide in the same month.
